description: From the past participle of nim (“to take”). Compare German benommen (“dazed, numb”). The final ⟨b⟩ is a later addition to the spelling; it was never pronounced, and did not appear in the original word.

entries.meaning: Physically unable to feel, not having the power of sensation.
Emotionally unable to feel or respond in a normal way.
examples: numb with shock; numb with boredom

verbs.description: numb (third-person singular simple present numbs, present participle numbing, simple past and past participle numbed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to become numb (physically or emotionally).
examples: The dentist gave me novocaine to numb my tooth before drilling, thank goodness.
When I first heard the news, I was numbed by the shock.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause (a feeling) to be less intense.
examples: He turned to alcohol to numb his pain.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause (the mind, faculties, etc.) to be less acute.
examples: […]  hunger, fatigue, and despairing hopelessness had numbed his brain  […]
[…]  after fumbling with numbing fingers for ten or fifteen minutes, he waved his hand with a gesture of despair  […]
